{{Infobox scientist |name = Elizabeth Riddle Graves |image = File:Elizabeth Riddle Graves.jpg | caption = Elizabeth R. Graves's Los Alamos identity card |image_size = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1916|1|23}} |birth_place = [[Nashville, Tennessee]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1972|1|6|1916|1|23}} |death_place = [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]] |citizenship = United States of America |field = [[Physics]] |work_institution = [[Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory]] |alma_mater = [[University of Chicago]] |doctoral_advisor = [[Samuel K. Allison]]{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} | thesis_title = Energy Released from Be 9 (d, α) Li 7 and the Production of Li 7 | thesis_year = 1940 | thesis_url = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |known_for = Physics of neutrons |prizes = }} '''Elizabeth Riddle Graves''' (25 January 1916 – 6 January 1972) was a pioneer in the physics of [[neutron]]s and the detection and measurement of fast neutrons. During [[World War II]], she worked in the [[Metallurgical Laboratory]] and at the [[Los Alamos Laboratory]], becoming a group leader there after the war.
==Biography== Elizabeth Riddle was born in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], on 23 January 1916 to James Marion Riddle from [[South Carolina]] and Georgia Clymetra Boykin from [[Arkansas]]. She had two brothers, James Marion Riddle Jr. and John Burwell Boykin Riddle. Around 1921, the Riddle family moved to Chicago, Illinois.<ref>{{cite web |title=United States Census, 1930 |publisher=FamilySearch |url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:XSGM-XVS |accessdate=15 August 2015}} Elizabeth B Riddle in household of James M Riddle, Chicago (Districts 0751-1000), Cook, Illinois, United States; citing enumeration district (ED) 0765, sheet 12A, family 145, line 4, NARA microfilm publication T626 (Washington D.C.: National Archives and Records Administration, 2002), roll 449; FHL microfilm 2,340,184.</ref>
Riddle entered the [[University of Chicago]], where she was known as "Diz".<ref name="Sun">{{cite book |last=Howes |first=Ruth H. |year=1999 |first2=Caroline L. |last2=Herzenberg |title=Their Day in the Sun: Women of the Manhattan Project |publisher=Temple University |isbn=978-0-585-38881-6 |oclc=49569088 |pp=48–50 }}</ref> She earned her [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[physics]] in 1936,<ref name="Bio"/> and developed a keen interest in the physics of [[neutrons]], particularly the detection and measurement of [[fast neutrons]].<ref>{{cite journal |journal=[[Physics Today]] |volume=25 |issue=4 p=67 |pages=67 |date=April 1972 |title=Elizabeth R. Graves |doi=10.1063/1.3070831 }}</ref> She earned her [[PhD]] in 1940, writing her thesis on the "Energy Released from Be 9 (d, α) Li 7 and the Production of Li 7" under the supervision of [[Samuel K. Allison]].<ref name="Bio">{{cite book |title=The Biographical dictionary of women in science : pioneering lives from ancient times to the mid-20th century |first=Marilyn |last=Ogilvie |first2=Joy |last2=Harvey |location=New York |publisher=Routledge |year=2000 |pp=522–523 |isbn=9780415920407 |oclc=803021974 }}</ref><ref name="Thesis"/>
While there, she met and married [[Alvin C. Graves]], a fellow physics major.<ref name="Post">{{cite news |last=Becker |first=Bill |title=The Man Who Sets Off Atomic Bombs |newspaper=[[The Saturday Evening Post]] |date=April 19, 1952| pages=32–33, 185–188}}</ref> Jobs were hard to find during the [[Great Depression]]. Alvin remained at the University of Chicago as a research fellow and an assistant professor until 1939, when he moved to the [[University of Texas]],<ref name="Post" /> but Elizabeth was unable to secure a job there as well due to its anti-[[nepotism]] rules, which tended to discriminate against women.<ref name="Sun" />
In 1942 Alvin was invited back to the University of Chicago by [[Arthur H. Compton]] to join the [[Manhattan Project]]'s [[Metallurgical Laboratory]]. <ref name="Post" /> Elizabeth found employment there as well, working with [[Enrico Fermi]] on the calculations involved in determining the feasibility of a [[nuclear chain reaction]], which eventually led to the development of [[Chicago Pile-1]], the world's first nuclear reactor.<ref name="Bio"/>
In 1943 they joined the Manhattan Project's [[Los Alamos Laboratory]] in [[New Mexico]]. With Texas in mind, Alvin made it a condition of his going there that Elizabeth also be given a job. As it turned out, she almost certainly would have been recruited anyway. She was one of the few scientists who knew about fast neutron scattering, which was crucial to [[nuclear weapon design]], and who knew how to operate the [[Cockcroft–Walton accelerator]] that had been brought from the [[University of Illinois]].<ref name="Sun" />
At the time of the [[Trinity nuclear test]] in 1945, Elizabeth was seven months pregnant with her first child. They therefore requested that they be assigned to a post far from the blast. They listened to Allison's countdown to the explosion on the radio, and using [[Geiger counter]]s, they monitored the test's [[radioactive fallout]], which took until the afternoon to reach them. Elizabeth finished an experiment while in labor, timing her contractions with a stopwatch.<ref name="Sun" /> The child was a healthy daughter, Marilyn Edith.<ref name="Post" /> Alvin and Elizabeth had two more children, Alvin Palmer and Elizabeth Anne.<ref name="Bio"/>
They remained in Los Alamos after the war. Elizabeth became a group leader in the experimental physics division in 1950, and researched neutron interactions with matter and material.<ref name="Bio"/><ref name="Colleen Coyne">{{cite web |url=http://scholarworks.bgsu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1037&context=honorsprojects |last=Coyne |first=Colleen |date=29 April 2013 |title=Female Scientists, the Military, and Informing Policy |publisher=Bowling Green State University |accessdate=18 May 2016}}</ref> She died of cancer at Bataan Memorial Hospital in [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]],<ref name="Bio"/> on 6 January 1972, and was buried at Guaje Pines Cemetery, Los Alamos, Los Alamos County, New Mexico.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:QVK6-YN89 |publisher=Family Search |accessdate=15 August 2015 |title=Elizabeth Riddle Graves}}</ref><ref>{{findagrave |grid=39395345 |title=Elizabeth Riddle Graves |accessdate=18 May 2016}}</ref>
==Select Publications==
===Patents=== *Low voltage 14 MeV neutron source.<ref>Graves, E. R., & Little Jr, Robert N. (1959). {{US Patent|2906903}}. Washington, DC: U.S. Patent and Trademark Office.</ref>
===Dissertation and Thesis=== *Energy Released from Be 9 (d, α) Li 7 and the Production of Li 7. 1940.<ref name="Thesis">{{Cite journal |title=Energy Release from Be9(d,α)Li7 and the Production of Li7 |last=Graves |first=Elizabeth Riddle |journal=[[Physical Review]] |issn= |volume=57 |issue=10 |pages=855–862 |date=May 1940 |doi=10.1103/PhysRev.57.855 |bibcode=1940PhRv...57..855G }}</ref>
====Thesis==== {{quote| The α-particles from Be9(d,α)Li7 have been investigated with a variable air pressure absorption cell, ionization chamber and linear amplifier. It has been established that there are two groups of α-particles differing at 760 mm pressure and 15°C by 3.08±0.10 mm range reduced to zero bombarding voltage. The groups have been shown to be associated with the production of Li7 in the ground state and in an excited state. At 239 kv bombarding voltage, the excited state is formed 1.7 times as often as the ground state. The energy balance, Q, associated with the production of the ground state has been determined to be 7.093±0.022 Mev. The energy of the excited level has been determined to be 494±16 kev. The total yield curve for α-particles has been investigated from 235 kv to 390 kv bombarding voltage. The measured value for the energy of the excited level in Li7 is discussed in connection with values from other reactions in which Li7 is an end product and with γ-ray measurements of the level.<ref name="Thesis"/> }}

{{Infobox company| | name = Enumeral Biomedical Holdings, Inc. | type = [[Public company|Public]] | traded_as = {{OTCQB|ENUM}} | foundation = 2009 | hq_location_city = {{nowrap|[[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]<ref name="keown2018biospace" />}} | hq_location_country = United States | key_people = {{unbulleted list|John Rydzewski {{small|([[Chairman]])}}|Kevin G. Sarney {{small|(interim [[CEO]], 2018)}}<ref name="sec8kJan2018" />{{rp|Signatures}}}} | industry = [[Biotechnology]] | products = [[Monoclonal antibodies]] targeting [[immune checkpoint]] proteins | num_employees = 10 (2017)<ref name="keown2017biospace" /> | homepage = {{URL|www.enumeral.com}} }} '''Enumeral''' was a [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]-based [[biotechnology]] company which developed [[monoclonal antibody]] immunotherapies through an 'immunoprofiling' platform that allowed it to scan the human immune microenvironment and identify and validate potential drug candidates. The company filed for [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 11 bankruptcy]] and arranged to sell its assets to Xoma Corporation in January 2018.
== The company ==
Enumeral was founded in 2009 to bring together various immunoprofiling technologies from [[Harvard University]], [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], the [[Whitehead Institute for Biomedical Research]] and [[Massachusetts General Hospital]].<ref>{{cite web|title=10-Q: Enumeral Biomedical Holdings Inc|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/10-q-enumeral-biomedical-holdings-inc-2015-11-10|publisher=Marketwatch.com|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> The company's Scientific Founder was Christopher Love, Associate Professor of Chemical Engineering at MIT; the Executive Chairman is John Rydzewskand and its CEO is Arthur Tinkelenberg. In 2014 the company was taken public through a [[reverse takeover]] into a shell called Cerulean Group. Its stock is traded [[OTC Markets Group|OTC]] in the US, with trading in the OTCQB marketplace tier commencing on 4 August 2014.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/pr-2014-08-04.php|title=Enumeral Biomedical Raises $21.5 Million from New and Current Investors, Begins Public Trading|last=|first=|date=August 4, 2014|work=|accessdate=December 27, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150322141209/http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/pr-2014-08-04.php|archive-date=January 5, 2016|publisher=Enumeral}}</ref> The stock code is ENUM.
By 2015, Enumeral had completed pre-clinical development of [[PD-1 inhibitor|PD-1 inhibitors]] and sought partners to enter clinical development with.<ref name="keown2017biospace">{{Cite news|url=https://www.biospace.com/article/cambridge-biotech-enumeral-biomedical-has-cash-to-fund-its-operations-only-into-next-month-/|title=Cambridge Biotech Enumeral Biomedical Has Cash to Fund Its Operations Only Into Next Month|last=Keown|first=Alex|date=May 30, 2017|work=|access-date=July 20, 2018|publisher=BioSpace}}</ref> In December 2016, Enumeral completed raising {{US$|3.4 million}} to fund long-term development plans, but by May 2017, the company announced it only had sufficient cash on hand to fund operations through June 2017.<ref name="keown2017biospace" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/news/2017/05/26/cambridge-biotech-enumeral-faces-uncertain-future.html|title=Cambridge biotech Enumeral faces uncertain future as cash dries up|last=Stendahl|first=Max|date=May 26, 2017|work=Boston Business Journal|access-date=July 20, 2018}}</ref> Shortly thereafter, in June, the company dismissed its R&D research staff.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.biospace.com/article/faltering-enumeral-biomedical-cuts-r-and-d-staff-alters-executive-compensation-deal-/|title=Faltering Enumeral Biomedical Cuts R&D Staff, Alters Executive Compensation Deal|last=Terry|first=Mark|date=June 20, 2017|work=|access-date=July 20, 2018|publisher=BioSpace}}</ref> In August 2017, Enumeral was kicked out of its headquarters in Cambridge due to non-payment of rent and other fees.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.biospace.com/article/enumeral-biomedical-gets-evicted-as-it-winds-down-operations-/|title=Enumeral Biomedical Gets Evicted as it Winds Down Operations|last=Terry|first=Mark|date=August 29, 2017|work=|access-date=July 20, 2018|publisher=BioSpace}}</ref> The Cambridge headquarters was also the home of [[Celgene]] and Unum Therapeutics.<ref name=":1" /> By the time the company lost its headquarters, Arthur Tinkelenberg was being described as the company's "former president and chief executive officer".<ref name=":0" /> In January 2018, Enumeral struck a deal with Xoma Corporation, located in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], to sell its assets for {{US$|1.6 million}}, while concurrently filing for [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 11 bankruptcy]].<ref name="keown2018biospace">{{Cite news|url=https://www.biospace.com/article/unique-cambridge-s-enumeral-filed-for-bankruptcy-sells-assets-to-bay-area-s-xoma/|title=Cambridge's Enumeral Filed for Bankruptcy, Sells Assets to Bay Area's XOMA|last=Keown|first=Alex|date=February 7, 2018|work=|access-date=July 21, 2018|publisher=BioSpace}}</ref><ref name="sec8kJan2018">{{Cite report|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1561551/000161577418000637/s108535_8-k.htm|title=Form 8-K: Enumeral Biomedical Holdings, Inc.|last=|first=|date=January 26, 2018|publisher=U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|issue=|doi=|volume=|pmid=|access-date=July 20, 2018}}</ref>{{Rp|item 1.03}}
== Platform ==
Enumeral's platform consists of various proprietary cellular libraries derived from target-specific immunized sources or from human patient donors. The platform has three main parts:
*'''Microengraving.''' This platform has its origins in work which Love et al. published in the journal ''[[Nature Biotechnology]]'' in 2006. Their foundational paper showed that it was possible to quickly capture a large mass of antibody-producing cells through engraved microarrays based on [[Intaglio (printmaking)|intaglio]] printing, where those arrays were carrying the secreted products of single cells.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Love JC |author2=Ronan JL |author3=Grotenbreg GM |author4=van der Veen AG |author5=Ploegh HL. |title=A microengraving method for rapid selection of single cells producing antigen-specific antibodies |journal=Nat. Biotechnol. |volume=24 |issue=6 |pages=703–7 |date=June 1, 2006 |doi=10.1038/nbt1210 |pmid=16699501 }}{{closed access}}</ref> The Love group elaborated on the utility of this microengraving technology in 2008 in two key papers. In the first they applied it to [[Peripheral blood mononuclear cell|PBMCs]] from a [[Diabetes mellitus type 1|Type I diabetic]] patient and reported that a small percentage of [[CD19]]+ B cells were secreting [[proinsulin]]-reactive antibodies.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Bradshaw EM |author2=Kent SC |author3=Tripuraneni V |author4=Orban T |author5=Ploegh HL |author6=Hafler DA |author7=Love JC. |title=Concurrent detection of secreted products from human lymphocytes by microengraving: cytokines and antigen-reactive antibodies |journal=Clin Immunol. |volume=129 |issue=1 |pages=10–18 |date=October 1, 2008 |pmid=18675591 |doi=10.1016/j.clim.2008.06.009 |pmc=2577144 }}</ref> In the second they showed how the technology could be used to describe the different kinds of antibodies produced during a multipart vaccination.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Story CM |author2=Papa E |author3=Hu CC |author4=Ronan JL |author5=Herlihy K |author6=Ploegh HL |author7=Love JC. |title=Profiling antibody responses by multiparametric analysis of primary B cells |journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A |volume=105 |issue=46 |pages=17902–7 |date=November 18, 2008 |pmid=19004776 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0805470105 |pmc=2584674 }}</ref> In 2010 the Love lab demonstrated that its microengraving technology could be used to quantify the rates of secretion of up to four [[cytokine]]s simultaneously released from individual viable primary immune cells, and that, among other things, primary [[T cell]]s with specific profiles of secretion could be recovered and expanded ''in vitro''.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Han Q |author2=Bradshaw EM |author3=Nilsson B |author4=Hafler DA |author5=Love JC. |title=Multidimensional analysis of the frequencies and rates of cytokine secretion from single cells by quantitative microengraving |journal=Lab Chip |volume=10 |issue=11 |pages=1391–1400 |date=June 7, 2010 |pmid=20376398 |doi=10.1039/b926849a |pmc=3128808 }}</ref> In 2011 the Love lab provided proof that microengraving would allow multiple fresh [[CD8]]+ T cells to be evaluated for their cytotoxic activity and cytokine secretion.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Varadarajan N |author2=Julg B |author3=Yamanaka YJ |author4=Chen H |author5=Ogunniyi AO |author6=McAndrew E |author7=Porter LC |author8=Piechocka-Trocha A |author9=Hill BJ |author10=Douek DC |author11=Pereyra F |author12=Walker BD |author13=Love JC. |title=A high-throughput single-cell analysis of human CD8⁺ T cell functions reveals discordance for cytokine secretion and cytolysis |journal=J Clin Invest |volume=121 |issue=11 |pages=4322–31 |date=November 1, 2011 |pmid=21965332 |doi=10.1172/JCI58653 |pmc=3204845 }}</ref> A 2013 paper from the Love lab reported the use of microengraving in evaluating the expression of pro-[[Angiogenesis|angiogenic]] ELR+ CXC [[chemokine]]s by colorectal tumor and stromal cells.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Adalsteinsson VA |author2=Tahirova N |author3=Tallapragada N |author4=Yao X |author5=Campion L |author6=Angelini A |author7=Douce TB |author8=Huang C |author9=Bowman B |author10=Williamson CA |author11=Kwon DS |author12=Wittrup KD |author13=Love JC. |title=Single cells from human primary colorectal tumors exhibit polyfunctional heterogeneity in secretions of ELR+ CXC chemokines. |journal=Integr Biol (Camb). |volume=5 |issue=10 |pages=1272–81 |date=October 5, 2013 |pmid=23995780 |doi=10.1039/c3ib40059j |pmc=4034677 }}</ref> The Love lab published a review on various single-cell technologies for monitoring immune systems, including the microengraving approach, in ''[[Nature Immunology]]'' in 2014.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Chattopadhyay PK |author2=Gierahn TM |author3=Roederer M |author4=Love JC. |title=Single-cell technologies for monitoring immune systems |journal=Nat Immunol |volume=15 |issue=2 |pages=128–35 |date=February 1, 2014 |pmid=24448570 |doi=10.1038/ni.2796 |pmc=4040085 }}</ref>
*'''Checkpoint discovery'''. This technology allows new immune checkpoints in T cells to be discovered. It does so through the identification of [[small hairpin RNA]] molecules involved in the release of blocks on T-cell proliferation at the time of tumour antigen recognition. This technology was discovered in the laboratory of Dr Kai Wucherpfennig at the [[Dana–Farber Cancer Institute]] and was published in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' in 2014.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Zhou P |author2=Shaffer DR |author3=Alvarez Arias DA |author4=Nakazaki Y |author5=Pos W |author6=Torres AJ |author7=Cremasco V |author8=Dougan SK |author9=Cowley GS |author10=Elpek K |author11=Brogdon J |author12=Lamb J |author13=Turley SJ |author14=Ploegh HL |author15=Root DE |author16=Love JC |author17=Dranoff G |author18=Hacohen N |author19=Cantor H |author20=Wucherpfennig KW. |title=In vivo discovery of immunotherapy targets in the tumour microenvironment. |journal=Nature |volume=506 |issue=7486 |pages=52–7 |date=February 6, 2014 |pmid=24476824 |doi=10.1038/nature12988 |pmc=4052214 }}</ref> Kai Wucherpfennig currently serves on Enumeral's Scientific Advisory Board.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enumeral.com/about-us/advisors.php|title=Enumeral Scientific Advisory Board|last=|first=|date=|website=Enumeral.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105122128/http://www.enumeral.com/about-us/advisors.php|archive-date=January 5, 2016|dead-url=|accessdate=28 December 2015}}{{self-published source|date=July 2018}}</ref>
*'''Whole-exome sequencing'''. This technology, first unveiled in ''Nature Biotechnology'' in 2014, involves the sequencing of whole [[exome]]s of circulating tumor cells by means of cell enrichment and isolation, genomic amplification, library qualification and 'census-based' sequencing.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Lohr JG |author2=Adalsteinsson VA |author3=Cibulskis K |author4=Choudhury AD |author5=Rosenberg M |author6=Cruz-Gordillo P |author7=Francis JM |author8=Zhang CZ |author9=Shalek AK |author10=Satija R |author11=Trombetta JJ |author12=Lu D |author13=Tallapragada N |author14=Tahirova N |author15=Kim S |author16=Blumenstiel B |author17=Sougnez C |author18=Lowe A |author19=Wong B |author20=Auclair D |author21=Van Allen EM |author22=Nakabayashi M |author23=Lis RT |author24=Lee GS |author25=Li T |author26=Chabot MS |author27=Ly A |author28=Taplin ME |author29=Clancy TE |author30=Loda M |author31=Regev A |author32=Meyerson M |author33=Hahn WC |author34=Kantoff PW |author35=Golub TR |author36=Getz G |author37=Boehm JS |author38=Love JC. |title=Whole-exome sequencing of circulating tumor cells provides a window into metastatic prostate cancer. |journal=Nat. Biotechnol. |volume=32 |issue=5 |pages=479–84 |date=May 1, 2014 |pmid=24752078 |doi=10.1038/nbt.2892 |pmc=4034575 |url=https://dash.harvard.edu/bitstream/handle/1/13454751/4034575.pdf?sequence=1 }}</ref>
== Anti PD-1 antibodies ==
An early commercial interest of Enumeral has focused on PD-1, currently targeted by two FDA-approved monoclonal antibody drugs - [[Pembrolizumab|Keytruda]], from [[Merck & Co.]], and [[Nivolumab|Opdivo]], from [[Bristol-Myers Squibb]]. In 2015 Enumeral reported that it had used its platform to raise anti-PD-1 antibodies that did not compete with Keytruda or Opdivo for binding to PD-1, nor did they appear to compete with PD-1's [[Ligand (biochemistry)|ligand]], [[PD-L1]]. These potentially [[allosteric]] antibodies also produced more [[interferon gamma]] and showed dose-dependent increases in T cell [[CD25]] expression.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Enumeral Announces Identification of Anti-PD-1 Antibodies with Potential for Differentiated Mechanism of Action|date=September 24, 2015|publisher=Enumeral|url=http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/news-events-press-release-2015-09-24.php|accessdate=December 28, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105104109/http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/news-events-press-release-2015-09-24.php|archive-date=January 5, 2016}}{{Self-published source|date=July 2018}}</ref> Further, Enumeral's antibodies caused higher T cell activation in ''ex vivo'' human assays than the currently marketed anti-PD-1 antibodies<ref>{{cite press release|title=Enumeral Reports That Its Novel Class of Anti-PD-1 Antibodies Elicits Higher T Cell Activation in Ex Vivo Human Assays than Currently Marketed Anti-PD-1 Antibodies|date=November 3, 2015|publisher=Enumeral|url=http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/news-events-press-release-2015-11-03.php|accessdate=28 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105111315/http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/news-events-press-release-2015-11-03.php|archive-date=January 5, 2016}}{{Self-published source|date=July 2018}}</ref> and, in that same setting, in combination with one of the marketed antibodies, could elicit an additive effect on T cell activation.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Enumeral Reports That Its Novel Class of Potentially Allosteric Anti-PD-1 Antibodies Can Elicit an Additive Effect on T Cell Activation in Ex Vivo Human Assays When Used in Combination With A Currently Marketed Anti-PD-1 Antibody|url=http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/news-events-press-release-2015-11-18.php|accessdate=27 December 2015|publisher=Enumeral|date=November 18, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105040218/http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/news-events-press-release-2015-11-18.php |archive-date=January 5, 2016 }}{{self-published source|date=July 2018}}</ref> Enumeral expects to take an anti-PD-1 antibody into clinical testing in 2016.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Enumeral Expands Scientific Advisory Board to Support Development of Novel Immunomodulators|url=http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/news-events-press-release-2015-06-04.php|accessdate=28 December 2015|publisher=Enumeral.com|date=June 4, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105111857/http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/news-events-press-release-2015-06-04.php |archive-date=January 5, 2016 }}{{self-published source|date=July 2018}}</ref>
== Merck collaboration ==
In December 2014 Enumeral announced a collaboration with Merck & Co. in which the two companies would use the Enumeral platform to interrogate the tumor microenvironment in [[colorectal cancer]] tissues obtained directly from patients, with the aim of identifying functional cellular responses to Merck-developed immuno-oncology products.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Enumeral and Merck Form Collaboration for Predicting Clinical Drug Response with Human-driven Immune Profiling Platform|url=http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/pr-2014-12-18.php|accessdate=27 December 2015|publisher=Enumeral.com|date=December 18, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105035253/http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/pr-2014-12-18.php |archive-date=January 5, 2016 }}{{self-published source|date=July 2018}}</ref> In September 2015 Enumeral announced that the Merck collaboration had achieved its first milestone, enabling Enumeral to receive a milestone payment from Merck.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Enumeral Achieves First Milestone in Merck Collaboration|url=http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/news-events-press-release-2015-09-08.php|accessdate=28 December 2015|publisher=Enumeral.com|date=September 8, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105121906/http://www.enumeral.com/news-events/news-events-press-release-2015-09-08.php |archive-date=January 5, 2016 }}{{self-published source|date=July 2018}}</ref>

'''Equivalent input''' (also '''input-referred''' or '''input-related'''), is a method of referring to the signal or noise level at the output of a system as if it were an input to the same system. This is accomplished by removing all signal changes (e.g. [[amplifier]] [[Gain (electronics)|gain]], [[transducer]] [[sensitivity (electronics)|sensitivity]], etc.) to get the units to match the input.<ref name="IEC61000-4-3">[http://webstore.iec.ch/Webstore/webstore.nsf/Artnum_PK/39224 IEC61000-4-3], Electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) - Part 4-3: Testing and measurement techniques - Radiated, radio-frequency, electromagnetic field immunity test</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aes.org/par/e/#ein|title=AES Pro Audio Reference - EIN|last=|first=|date=|website=www.aes.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref>
== Examples == === Equivalent Input Noise (EIN) === A [[microphone]] converts [[acoustical]] [[energy]] to [[electrical]] energy. Microphones have some level of electrical [[noise]] at their output. This noise may have contributions from random [[diaphragm (acoustics)|diaphragm]] movement, [[thermal noise]], or a dozen other sources, but those can all be thought of as an imaginary acoustic noise source injecting sound into the (now noiseless) microphone. The units on this noise are no longer [[volts]], but units of sound pressure ([[pascals]] or [[dBSPL]]), which can be directly compared to the desired sound pressure inputs.
=== Input-Related Interference Level (IRIL) === A device which uses a [[microphone]] may be susceptible to [[electromagnetic interference]] which causes [[sonic artifact]]s. The problem is not in the microphone, but the interference level can be ''related'' back to the input to compare to the level of typical inputs to see how [[Hearing|audible]] the artifact is.

{{About|the cleaning tool|1925 short film|Feather Duster}}
{{refimprove|date=September 2009}} [[Image:OstrichFeatherDuster.jpg|thumb|150px|Ostrich feather duster]] A '''feather duster''' is an implement used for cleaning. It consists typically of a wooden-dowel handle and feathers from either the male or female [[ostrich]] bird that are wound onto the handle by a wrapped wire. Dusters vary in size but are most often between {{convert|14|to|32|inch|cm}} in total length. Some dusters have a retractable casing instead of a dowel handle. These dusters are typically used by [[Rack Jobber|rack-jobbers]] and [[truck driver]]s who need to dust store shelves, and like to retract the feathers into the handle to avoid damage.
Feather dusters are effective in dusting tight areas, or areas where there are a lot of odds and ends to dust around. The individual feathers are able to penetrate through the knick-knacks and pull the dust out of the area without disturbing items. On large open surfaces or walls, or in trying to get [[spider web]]s in the ceiling, either a feather duster or other dusters like [[lambswool]] or synthetic dusters will work.
==History== In 1870, the original idea for the feather duster was conceived in a broom factory in [[Jones County, Iowa]], U.S.A. farmer brought a bundle of turkey feathers into the factory asking if they could be used to assembly a brush. E.E. Hoag used these feathers to invent the first feather duster. Using a short [[broom stick]] and splitting the feathers with a [[pocket knife]], the duster was found to be too stiff for use. In 1874, the Hoag Duster Company was founded, which became a pioneer of feather dusters in the U.S. state of [[Iowa]].<ref>{{cite book|title=History of Jones County, Iowa: past and present, Volume 1|publisher=S. J. Clarke publishing co.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b5gUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA477&sig=2uybIHwg7E7Gwmg_1kwb2NC-1L4&hl=en#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
In 1874, Susan Hibbard of [[Geneva Lake]], [[Wisconsin]], U.S. used discarded turkey feathers to invent a feather duster.<ref>{{cite web|title=American Experience|publisher=PBS|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/telephone/sfeature/index.html}}</ref> Hibbard filed a patent (U.S. patent #177,939) on November 13, 1874 which was issued on May 30, 1876.<ref>{{cite web|title=Improvement in Feather Dusters|publisher=United States Patent and Trademark Office|url= http://www.google.com/patents?id=roBWAAAAEBAJ&printsec=abstract#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> After a hard fought legal battle against her husband, George Hibbard, and the National Feather Duster Company in December 1881, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]] in [[Chicago]] ruled in favor of Susan Hibbard giving her [[Priority right|priority]] of invention of the feather duster.<ref>{{cite book|title=Cases argued and determined in the Circuit and District courts of the United States: for the Seventh judicial circuit.|publisher=Callaghan & co.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9C63AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA76&lpg=PA76&dq=Susan+Hibbard+and+feather+duster&source=bl&ots=b1cuxrFpMm&sig=7oIDYEdfe4DnKd9qtxE3eiT5-rA&hl=en&ei=Mdb-TdHUEsiCtgeyz8S8Dg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
South African ostrich feather dusters were developed in [[Johannesburg]], South Africa by missionary, broom factory manager, Harry S. Beckner in 1903. He felt that the Ostrich feathers made a convenient tool for cleaning up the machines at the broom factory. His first ostrich feather dusters were wound on broom handles using the foot powered kick winders and the same wire used to attach broom straw. The Chicago Feather Duster Company was established in 1875. They received a patent for the head of the duster on September 17, 1907 along with a patent for the cuff on December 22, 1906.
The first ostrich feather duster company in the United States was formed in 1913 by Harry S. Beckner and his brother George Beckner in [[Athol, Massachusetts|Athol]], [[Massachusetts]] and has survived till this day as the Beckner Feather Duster Company under the care of George Beckner's great granddaughter, Margret Fish Rempher. Today the largest manufacturer of Ostrich Feather Dusters is Klein Karoo International (Feathers) which is located in [[Oudtshoorn]], South Africa.
The feather duster was considered a status symbol in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}}
==Types== [[File:Feather dusters.jpg|thumb|A common Asian feather duster made of chicken feathers attached to a bamboo stick]] There are several types of feathers used in feather dusters, but [[ostrich]] feathers are most often used. Feathers for dusters are the ostrich family's most valuable industrial commodity.
Black ostrich feathers come from the male ostrich and are very soft with feathers that are more "stringy" in nature. Gray ostrich feathers are more stark than the black feathers and are often sold at [[grocery store]]s. Floss ostrich feathers are the most soft and delicate feathers and come from underneath the bird's wings. Floss ostrich feathers are more expensive. Chick feathers are more pointed and stark than ostrich feathers, are usually sold at very low prices.
Throughout China, feather dusters are normally made of chicken feathers. They are attached to a length of bamboo, and unlike Western dusters, are commonly present along most of the stick rather than just the end.
== Mechanics of function == [[Ostrich]] feather dusters are effective by means of the tiny [[barbule]]s on the feathers themselves that act as fingers to collect the dust. They are often used around electronics because of their resistance to [[static electricity]].{{reference needed|date=October 2018}}

[[Image:Couverture-anti-feu-p1010028.jpg|thumb|Fire blanket being smothered on flames]] [[Image:Feu-de-paille-couverture.ogg|thumb|Extinguishing of a fire with a fire blanket]] A '''fire blanket''' is a safety device designed to extinguish incipient (starting) [[fires]]. It consists of a sheet of a [[Fire-retardant material|fire retardant material]] which is placed over a fire in order to smother it.
Small fire blankets, such as for use in kitchens and around the home are usually made of [[fiberglass]] and sometimes kevlar, and are folded into a quick-release contraption for ease of storage.
Fire blankets, along with fire extinguishers, are fire safety items that can be useful in case of a fire. These nonflammable blankets are helpful in temperatures up to 900 degrees and are useful in smothering fires by not allowing any oxygen to the fire. Due to its simplicity, a fire blanket may be more helpful for someone who is inexperienced with fire extinguishers.
Larger fire blankets, for use in [[laboratory]] and industrial situations, are often made of [[wool]] (sometimes treated with a flame retardant fluid). These blankets are usually mounted in vertical quick-release container so that they can be easily pulled out and wrapped round a person whose clothes are on fire.
==Dangers==
=== Asbestos in old blankets === Some older fire blankets were made of woven [[asbestos]] fibers and are not [[National Fire Protection Association|NFPA]] rated. This can pose a hazard during the decommissioning of old equipment.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}}
=== Extinguishing oil/fat fires === After initial investigation in 2013, and later in 2014, the Netherlands Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority issued a statement that fire blankets should never be used to extinguish an oil/fat fire such as a chip pan fire, even if the icons or text on the blanket indicates the blanket may be used in such a case. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nvwa.nl/actueel/nieuws/nieuwsbericht/2042901/niet-alle-blusdekens-blussen-olie-en-vetbranden|archive-url=https://archive.is/20141107112838/https://www.nvwa.nl/actueel/nieuws/nieuwsbericht/2042901/niet-alle-blusdekens-blussen-olie-en-vetbranden|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-11-07|title=NVWA - Niet alle blusdekens blussen olie- en vetbranden|publisher=}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vwa.nl/actueel/waarschuwingen/nieuwsbericht/2056081/belangrijke-veiligheidswaarschuwing-blusdekens-niet-geschikt-voor-frituurbrande|title=NVWA - Belangrijke veiligheidswaarschuwing: blusdekens niet geschikt voor frituurbranden|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141107113015/http://www.vwa.nl/actueel/waarschuwingen/nieuwsbericht/2056081/belangrijke-veiligheidswaarschuwing-blusdekens-niet-geschikt-voor-frituurbrande|archivedate=2014-11-07|df=}}</ref> <ref>http://www.vwa.nl/txmpub/files/?p_file_id=2207490{{dead link|date=September 2017|fix-attempted =yes}}</ref> This includes fire blankets which have been tested according to BS EN 1869. <ref>https://www.nvwa.nl/txmpub/files/?p_file_id=2204607{{dead link|date=September 2017|fix-attempted = yes}}</ref> In the investigation out of the 22 tested fire blankets, 16 of the fire blankets themselves caught fire. In the other 6 the fire reignited when the blanket was removed after 17 minutes. The Dutch Fire Burn foundation reported <ref>{{cite web|url=http://brandwondenstichting.nl/nieuws/vlam-de-pan-niet-blussen-met-een-blusdeken/|title=Vlam in de pan: niet blussen met een blusdeken|work=Nederlandse Brandwonden Stichting|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107132628/http://brandwondenstichting.nl/nieuws/vlam-de-pan-niet-blussen-met-een-blusdeken/|archivedate=2014-11-07|df=}}</ref> several accidents involving the use of fire blankets when extinguishing oil/fat fires. Consumers may send in their existing fire blankets, which will then receive a sticker stating 'niet geschikt voor olie- en vetbranden' ("not suitable for oil- and fat fires"). New products will have this text printed, rather than stickered. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vwa.nl/actueel/mededelingen-consumentenartikelen/nieuwsbericht/2056082/nvwa-controleert-etikettering-blusdekens|title=NVWA - NVWA controleert etikettering blusdekens|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141107112933/https://www.vwa.nl/actueel/mededelingen-consumentenartikelen/nieuwsbericht/2056082/nvwa-controleert-etikettering-blusdekens|archivedate=2014-11-07|df=}}</ref>
==Operation== For a fire to burn, all three elements of the [[fire triangle]] must be present: heat, fuel and oxygen. The fire blanket is used to cut off the oxygen supply to the fire, thereby putting it out. The fire blanket must be sealed closely to a solid surface around the fire. Fire blankets usually have two pull down tails visible from outside the packaging. The user should place one hand on each tag and pull down simultaneously removing the blanket from the bag. The tails are located near the top of the fire blanket which allows the top lip of the fire blanket to fold back over the users' hands, protecting them from heat and direct contact burns.
==Maintenance== The [[Fire_Industry_Association|Fire Industry Association ("FIA")]] publish a "Code of Practice for the Commissioning and Maintenance of Fire Blankets Manufactured to BS EN 1869"<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fia.uk.com/resourceLibrary/cop-commissioning&maintenance-of-fire-blankets.html |title=Code of Practice for the Commissioning and Maintenance of Fire Blankets Manufactured to BS EN 1869 |publisher=Fire Industry Association |date=May 2016 |website=Fire Industry Association Website |access-date=May 21, 2018}}</ref>.
=== Annual Maintenance by Service Provider === The [[Fire_Industry_Association|FIA]]'s code of practice recommends that the responsible person ensures that such fire blankets are subject to annual maintenance by a competent service provider.
=== Service-life expectancy of fire blankets === It also recommends that consideration should be given to the replacement of fire blankets after seven years from the date of commissioning (or as otherwise specified by the fire blanket's manufacturer).
==See also== * [[Welding blanket]]

[[File:AI for Good Global Summit 2018 (41226107365).jpg|thumb]] '''Francesca Bria''' is an Italian [[information technologist]] and advisor on digital strategy, technology and information policy. She is the Chief Technology and Digital Innovation Officer for the [[Barcelona|City of Barcelona]] and she is the founder of the Decode Project, a EU-wide effort to reclaim data sovereignty of citizens.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/profile/francesca-bria|title=Francesca Bria|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref>
== Biography == Bria has a background in social science and innovation economics and an MSc in E-business and Innovation from the [[University College of London]], Birkbeck. She was a Senior Project Lead in the Innovation Lab. She was EU Coordinator of the D-CENT project on direct democracy and social digital currencies and principle investigator of the DSI project on digital social innovation in Europe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nesta.org.uk/team/francesca-bria/|title=Francesca Bria|website=nesta|language=en|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref>
Bria is a member of the Internet of Things Council and an advisor for the European Commission on Future Internet and Smart Cities policy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theinternetofthings.eu/francesca-bria|title=Francesca Bria {{!}} the internet of things|website=www.theinternetofthings.eu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref> She is also a member of the EC Expert Group on Open Innovation (OISPG)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ec.europa.eu/digital-single-market/en/open-innovation-strategy-and-policy-group|title=The Open Innovation Strategy and Policy Group|work=Digital Single Market|access-date=2018-10-13|language=en}}</ref> and a member of the European Research Cluster on the Internet of Things (IERC).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.internet-of-things-research.eu/index.html|title=IERC-European Research Cluster on the Internet of Things|website=www.internet-of-things-research.eu|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref>
Bria has been advising the [[City of Rome]] and the [[Region of Lazio]] on innovation policy, open technology, and open cities. She is also active in various grassroots movements advocating for [[open access]], knowledge commons and open, decentralised privacy aware technologies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nesta.org.uk/team/francesca-bria/|title=Francesca Bria|website=nesta|language=en|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref>
== Awards == In 2018, Bria was named in Europe's Top 50 Women In Tech, 50 women from across Europe who are putting technology at the heart of their businesses assembled by ''[[Forbes]].''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/top-tech-women/#436e6d1f4df0|title=The Top 50 Women In Tech 2018|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref>

'''Hydrogen fuel''' is a [[zero-emission]] [[fuel]] when burned with oxygen. It can be used in [[electrochemical cell]]s or [[internal combustion engine]]s to power vehicles or electric devices. It has begun to be used in commercial [[fuel cell vehicles]] such as passenger cars, and has been used in [[fuel cell bus]]es for many years. It is also used as a fuel for the propulsion of spacecraft.
[[Hydrogen]] is found in the first group and first period in the [[periodic table]], i.e. it is the first element on the periodic table, making it the lightest element. Since hydrogen gas is so light, it rises in the atmosphere and is therefore rarely found in its pure form, H<sub>2</sub>.<ref name="ReferenceA">Altork, L.N. & Busby, J. R. (2010 Oct). Hydrogen fuel cells: part of the solution. Technology & Engineering Teacher, 70(2), 22-27.</ref> In a flame of pure hydrogen gas, burning in air, the hydrogen (H<sub>2</sub>) reacts with [[oxygen]] (O<sub>2</sub>) to form [[water]] (H<sub>2</sub>O) and releases energy.
:2H<sub>2</sub>(g) + O<sub>2</sub>(g) → 2H<sub>2</sub>O(g) + energy
If carried out in atmospheric air instead of pure oxygen, as is usually the case, hydrogen combustion may yield small amounts of [[nitrogen oxide]]s, along with the water vapor.
The energy released enables hydrogen to act as a fuel. In an electrochemical cell, that energy can be used with relatively high efficiency. If it is used simply for heat, the usual [[Carnot's theorem (thermodynamics)#Applicability to fuel cells and batteries|thermodynamics]] limits on the [[thermal efficiency]] apply.
Hydrogen is usually considered an energy carrier, like electricity, as it must be produced from a primary energy source such as solar energy, biomass, electricity (e.g. in the form of solar PV or via wind turbines), or hydrocarbons such as natural gas or coal.<ref name="FSEC">Florida Solar Energy Center. (n.d.). Hydrogen Basics. Retrieved from: http://www.fsec.ucf.edu/en/consumer/hydrogen/basics/index.htm</ref> Conventional hydrogen production using natural gas induces significant environmental impacts; as with the use of any hydrocarbon, carbon dioxide is emitted.<ref name="Zehner 2012">{{cite book|last=Zehner|first=Ozzie|title=Green Illusions|year=2012|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|location=Lincoln and London|pages=1–169, 331–42|url=http://greenillusions.org}}</ref>
==Production== {{Main|Hydrogen production}} Because pure hydrogen does not occur naturally on Earth in large quantities, it usually requires a [[primary energy]] input to produce on an industrial scale.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=Feng|title=Thermodynamic analysis of high-temperature helium heated fuel reforming for hydrogen production|journal=[[International Journal of Energy Research]]|date=March 2015|volume=39|issue=3|pages=418–432|doi=10.1002/er.3263}}</ref> Common production methods include [[electrolysis]] and [[Steam reforming|steam-methane reforming]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jones|first1=J.C.|title=Energy-return-on-energy-invested for hydrogen fuel from the steam reforming of natural gas.|journal=Fuel|date=March 2015|volume=143|page=631|doi=10.1016/j.fuel.2014.12.027}}</ref> In electrolysis, electricity is run through water to separate the hydrogen and oxygen atoms. This method can use wind, solar, geothermal, hydro, fossil fuels, biomass, nuclear, and many other energy sources.<ref name="FSEC" /> Obtaining hydrogen from this process is being studied as a viable way to produce it domestically at a low cost. Steam-methane reforming, the current leading technology for producing hydrogen in large quantities,<ref>U.S. Department of Energy. (2007 Feb). Potential for hydrogen production from key renewable resources in the United States. (Technical Report NREL/TP-640-41134). National Renewable Energy Laboratory Golden, CO: Milbrandt, A. & Mann, M. Retrieved from: http://www.afdc.energy.gov/afdc/pdfs/41134.pdf</ref> extracts hydrogen from [[methane]]. However, this reaction releases fossil [[carbon dioxide]] and [[carbon monoxide]] into the atmosphere which are [[greenhouse gas]]es exogenous to the natural carbon cycle, and thus contribute to [[global warming]] which is rapidly heating the Earth's oceans and atmosphere.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Energy== Hydrogen is locked up in enormous quantities in water, hydrocarbons, and other organic matter. One of the challenges of using hydrogen as a fuel comes from being able to efficiently extract hydrogen from these compounds. Currently, steam reforming, which combines high-temperature steam with natural gas, accounts for the majority of the hydrogen produced.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.afdc.energy.gov/fuels/hydrogen_basics.html | title = Alternative Fuels Data Center: Hydrogen Basics | website = www.afdc.energy.gov | access-date = 2016-02-27 }}</ref> This method of hydrogen production occurs at temperatures between 700-1100°C, and has a resultant efficiency of between 60-75%.<ref name="Steam reforming">{{cite web|title=Hydrogen Production Technologies: Current State and Future Developments|url=https://www.hindawi.com/journals/cpis/2013/690627/|website=hindawi.com|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> Hydrogen can also be produced from water through electrolysis, which is less carbon intensive if the electricity used to drive the reaction does not come from fossil-fuel power plants but rather renewable or nuclear energy instead. The efficiency of water electrolysis is between about 70-80%,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Stolten|first1=Detlef|title=Hydrogen Science and Engineering: Materials, Processes, Systems and Technology|date=Jan 4, 2016|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn= 9783527674299 |page=898|url=https://books.google.hu/books?id=we5bCwAAQBAJ&dq|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ITM - Hydrogen Refuelling Infrastructure - February 2017|url=http://www.level-network.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/ITM-Power.pdf|website=level-network.com|accessdate=17 April 2018|page=12}}</ref> with a goal set to reach 82-86% efficiency by 2030 using proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolyzers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cost reduction and performance increase of PEM electrolysers|url=http://www.fch.europa.eu/sites/default/files/Nov22_Session3_Panel%205_Slot%202_NOVEL-MEGASTACK_Thomassen%20%28ID%202891376%29.pdf|website=fch.europa.eu|publisher=Fuel Cells and Hydrogen Joint Undertaking|accessdate=17 April 2018|page=9}}</ref> Once produced, hydrogen can be used in much the same way as natural gas - it can be delivered to fuel cells to generate electricity and heat, used in a combined cycle gas turbine to produce larger quantities of centrally produced electricity or burned to run a combustion engine; all methods producing no carbon or methane emissions.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ono|first1=Katsutoshi|title=Fundamental Theories on a Combined Energy Cycle of an Electrostatic Induction Electrolytic Cell and Fuel Cell to Produce Fully Sustainable Hydrogen Energy.|journal=Electrical Engineering in Japan|date=January 2015|volume=190|issue=2|pages=1–9|doi=10.1002/eej.22673}}</ref> In each case hydrogen is combined with oxygen to form water. The heat in a hydrogen flame is a radiant emission from the newly formed water molecules. The water molecules are in an excited state on initial formation and then transition to a ground state; the transition releasing thermal radiation. When burning in air, the temperature is roughly 2000 °C (the same as natural gas). Historically, carbon has been the most practical carrier of energy, as hydrogen and carbon combined are more volumetrically dense, although hydrogen itself has three times the [[energy density]] per weight as methane or gasoline. Although hydrogen is the smallest element and thus has a slightly higher propensity to leak from venerable natural gas pipes such as those made from iron, leakage from plastic (polythylene PE100) pipes is expected to be very low at about 0.001%.<ref>{{cite web|title=Energy Thoughts and Surprises|url=https://energy-surprises.blogspot.hu/2016/11/converting-gas-grid-to-hydrogen.html|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Sadler|first1=Dan|title=“100% hydrogen unlocks everything”|url=https://medium.com/@cH2ange/dan-sadler-100-hydrogen-unlocks-everything-dd725ef6aa70|website=medium.com|publisher=cH2ange|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref>
The reason steam methane reforming has traditionally been favoured over electrolysis is because whereas methane reforming directly uses natural gas, electrolysis requires electricity. As the cost of producing electricity (via wind turbines and solar PV) falls below the cost of natural gas, electrolysis becomes cheaper than SMR.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Philibert|first1=Cédric|title=Commentary: Producing industrial hydrogen from renewable energy|url=https://www.iea.org/newsroom/news/2017/april/producing-industrial-hydrogen-from-renewable-energy.html|website=www.iea.org/|publisher=International Energy Agency|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref>
==Uses== {{Main|Hydrogen economy}} Hydrogen fuel can provide [[motive power]] for [[liquid-propellant rocket]]s, cars, boats and airplanes, [[portable fuel cell applications]] or [[stationary fuel cell applications]], which can power an electric motor.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Colella|first1=W.G.|title=Switching to a U.S. hydrogen fuel cell vehicle fleet: The resultant change in emissions, energy use, and greenhouse gases.|journal=Journal of Power Sources|date=October 2005|volume=150|issue=1/2|pages=150–181|doi=10.1016/j.jpowsour.2005.05.092|bibcode=2005JPS...150..150C}}</ref> The problems of using hydrogen fuel in cars arise from the fact that hydrogen is [[Hydrogen_storage|difficult to store]] in either a high pressure tank or a cryogenic tank.<ref>{{cite book |last=Zubrin |first=Robert |author-link=Robert Zubrin |year=2007 |title=Energy Victory: Winning the War on Terror by Breaking Free of Oil |location=Amherst, New York |publisher=Prometheus Books |page=121 |isbn=978-1-59102-591-7}}</ref>
===Internal combustion engine conversions to hydrogen===
Combustion engines in commercial vehicles have been converted to run on a hydrogen-diesel mix in the UK, where up to 70% of emissions have been reduced during normal driving conditions. This eliminates range anxiety as the vehicles can fill up on diesel. Minor modifications are needed to the engines, as well as the addition of hydrogen tanks at a compression of 350 bars.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dalagan|first1=Maria Theresa|title=ULEMCO developing hydrogen-fuelled vehicles|url=https://www.freightwaves.com/news/hydrogen-retrofit-system|website=freightwaves.com|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref> Trials are now underway to test the efficiency of the 100% conversion of a Volvo FH16 heavy-duty truck to use only hydrogen. The range is expected to be 300km/17kg<ref>{{cite web|title=UK firm to demonstrate “world’s first” hydrogen-fuelled combustion engine truck|url=https://www.theengineer.co.uk/hydrogen-fuelled-combustion-engine-truck/|website=theengineer.co.uk|publisher=Centaur Media plc|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref>; which means an efficiency better than a standard diesel engine<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mårtensson|first1=Lars|title=Emissions from Volvo’s trucks|url=http://www.volvotrucks.com/content/dam/volvo/volvo-trucks/markets/global/pdf/our-trucks/Emis_eng_10110_14001.pdf|website=volvotrucks.com|accessdate=22 April 2018|page= 3}}</ref> (where the [[embodied energy]] of [[Gasoline gallon equivalent|1 gallon of gasoline is equal to 1 kilogram of hydrogen]]). At a low cost price for hydrogen (€5/kg),<ref>{{cite web|last1=André Løkke|first1=Jon|title=Wide Spread Adaption of Competitive Hydrogen Solution|url=http://nelhydrogen.com/assets/uploads/2018/03/2018-03-02-FC-EXPO-Nel_FINAL.pdf|website=nelhydrogen.com/|publisher=Nel ASA|accessdate=22 April 2018|page= 16}}</ref> significant fuel savings could be made via such a conversion in Europe or the UK. A lower price would be needed to compete with gasoline in the US, as gasoline is not exposed to high taxes at the pump.
Fuel cell engines are two to three times more efficient than combustion engines, meaning that much greater fuel economy is available using hydrogen in a fuel cell.
==See also== * [[Fuel cell vehicle]] * [[HCNG]] * [[Hydrogen compressor]] * [[Hydrogen safety]] * [[Hydrogen storage]] * [[Hydrogen technologies]] * [[Hydrogen vehicle]] * [[Oxyhydrogen flame]] * [[Photocatalytic water splitting]] to isolate hydrogen * [[Synthetic fuel]]
==References==
=== Notes === {{Reflist|30em}}
===Bibliography=== * {{cite web |last= McCarthy |first= John |title= Hydrogen |url= http://www-formal.stanford.edu/jmc/progress/hydrogen.html}}

{{Lowercase title}} {{Infobox information appliance | name = iSmartAlarm | aka = iSmartAlarm Home Security System | logo = File:ISmartAlarm Logo.png | image = File:ISmartAlarm Premium Package.png | founder = Raymond Meng | manufacturer = iSmart Alarm, Inc. | operating system = [[Android (operating system)|Android]] 4.0 or later{{cite web |url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.ifttt.ifttt| title= Google play-IFTTT | publisher= [[Google play]] | accessdate=19 August 2015}}
[[iOS]] 6.0 or later (iPhone, iPad, and iPod touch){{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/ifttt/id660944635?ls=1&mt=8/| title= iTunes preview-IFTTT | publisher= [[iTunes]] | accessdate=19 August 2015}} | language = English, French, Spanish, German, Italian, Portuguese | family = | type = Home Security | release date = {{start date and age|2013|6|28}} | lifespan = | unitsshipped = | media = | power = AC Power, Battery | sound = 110dB siren | camera = iCamera (Generation One), iCamera KEEP, SPOT | connectivity = [[Radio Frequency]], [[Wi-Fi]] | service = | compatibility = Android, iOS | website = {{URL|iSmartAlarm.com}} }} '''iSmartAlarm''' is a do-it-yourself ([[DIY]]) smart home security system [http://www.cnet.com/products/ismartalarm/ Do-it-yourself home alarm system changes the security game] controlled with a user’s [[smartphone]]. The system and devices are designed and manufactured by iSmart Alarm, Inc, a start-up based in [[Sunnyvale, California]]. The system uses a hub connected to a home’s router to allow users control of home security and home automation devices, including multiple wireless devices. Users can arm and disarm their system, and receive a push notifications, phone call, email, and text message if the system is triggered. The iSmartAlarm system is to be used as a self-monitored solution with no monthly fees and no contracts, as opposed to traditional monitored systems such as [[The ADT Corporation|ADT]] or [[Vivint]]. iSmartAlarm is currently a closed ecosystem, only operating with its own devices. Announcements have been made for future integrations with [[Google]] Thread Group, [[HomeKit]], and [[Z-Wave]] device support.{{cite news | url=http://www.cnet.com/news/ismartalarm-gets-ambitious-at-ces-2015/| title=iSmartAlarm gets ambitious at CES 2015 | date=January 7, 2015 | accessdate=March 13, 2015 | last=Crist|first= Ry | work=CNet}} On August 10, 2017, iSmart Alarm, Inc. announced the integration with Amazon Alexa. PRWeb. "[http://www.prweb.com/releases/2017/08/prweb14585697.htm iSmartAlarm Integrates with Amazon Alexa to Add Voice Control Capabilities to Smart Home Security]." Aug 10, 2017. Retrieved Dec 13, 2017. ==Development== iSmart Alarm, Inc. first announced the development of the iSmartAlarm Home Security System at the annual [[Consumer Electronics Show]] in 2013.{{cite news | url=https://techcrunch.com/video/ismart-alarm-home-security-demo/517633481/ | title=TechCrunch Home Security Demo - TechCrunch CES | date= | accessdate=March 16, 2015 | last= |first= | work= }} Launching with an [[Indiegogo]] crowdfunding campaign, the campaign was successful in raising $226,074 in pre-sales (against an original goal of $50,000).{{cite news | url= https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/ismartalarm-iphone-controlled-home-security-system-intelligent-and-affordable/x/1888248#home | title=iSmartAlarm - iPhone-controlled home security system | date= | accessdate=February 28, 2015 | last= |first= | work= }} After completion of the [[crowdfunding]] campaign, the iSmartAlarm began shipping to contributors on June 28, 2013.{{cite news | url=https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/ismartalarm-iphone-controlled-home-security-system-intelligent-and-affordable/x/1888248#activity | title=iSmartAlarm Indiegogo Updates | date= | accessdate=March 16, 2015 | last= |first= | work= }} iSmartAlarm also launched a new home security video camera on [[Indiegogo]] {{cite news | url=https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-icamera-keep-hd-video-from-ismartalarm/x/1888248 | title=The iCamera KEEP - HD Video from iSmartAlarm | date= | accessdate=March 16, 2015 | last= |first= | work= }} September 30, 2014. An [[IFTTT]] Channel was launched for the iSmartAlarm on March 18, 2015.{{cite news | url=http://www.cnet.com/news/ifttt-helps-ismartalarm-finally-talk-to-other-devices/| title=IFTTT helps iSmartAlarm finally talk to other devices | date=March 19, 2015 | accessdate=March 19, 2015 | last=Wollerton|first= Megan | work=CNet}} ==Overview== iSmartAlarm currently manufactures and supports the following devices. * The '''CubeOne''' is the hub of the system,{{cite news | url= http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/B1-GfwNmEkS.pdf | title=User Manual and Specifications | date= | accessdate=March 18, 2015 | last= |first= | work= }} allowing devices to communicate through the user’s home internet router. The CubeOne communicates wirelessly through a proprietary [[radio frequency]]. All users have the ability to monitor, manage, and control all devices from their [[iPhone]] and [[Android (operating system)]] devices. * The '''Motion Sensor'''{{cite news | url= http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/B1-GfwNmEkS.pdf | title=User Manual and Specifications | date= | accessdate=March 18, 2015 | last= |first= | work= }} allows users to identify movement in a 90° field of view from up to 30 meters * '''Contact Sensors'''{{cite news | url= http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/B1-GfwNmEkS.pdf | title=User Manual and Specifications | date= | accessdate=March 18, 2015 | last= |first= | work= }} operate as door and/or window sensors. If any sensor is separated from its counterpart by more than 3/4”, the system may be triggered if the system has been armed. * '''Remote Tags'''{{cite news | url= http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/B1-GfwNmEkS.pdf | title=User Manual and Specifications | date= | accessdate=March 18, 2015 | last= |first= | work= }} are basic control key fobs, allowing users to arm, disarm, and set off the 110 dB siren. * '''iCamera (Generation One)'''{{cite news | url= https://www.ismartalarm.com/productdetail#iCamera%E2%84%A2 | title=iCamera (Generation One) Product Details | date= | accessdate=February 28, 2015 | last= |first= | work= }} is the first video camera offered with the iSmartAlarm. The iCamera has pan and tilt controls, streaming on-demand video, night vision, and automated and manual still picture capture. The '''International Council on Clean Transportation''' (ICCT) is an independent [[nonprofit organization]] incorporated under [[Section 501(c)(3)]] of the US tax code. It provides technical and scientific analysis to environmental regulators. It is funded by the [[ClimateWorks Foundation]], the [[William and Flora Hewlett Foundation]], the [[Energy Foundation]], and the [[David and Lucile Packard Foundation]].
== Volkswagen emissions scandal == The ICCT commissioned researchers at [[West Virginia University]] to test [[Volkswagen]] [[diesel engine|diesel]] car emissions in 2013. In May 2014, ICCT alerted the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|US EPA]] and the [[California Air Resources Board]] that the models displayed much higher levels of [[nitrogen oxide emissions]] than permitted by law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eenews.net/assets/2015/09/21/document_cw_02.pdf|title=In-Use Emissions Testing of Light-Duty Diesel Vehicles in the United States|date=May 15, 2014|accessdate=September 22, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/09/22/usa-volkswagen-researchers-idUSL1N11S20620150922|title=Interview: West Virginia engineer proves to be a David to VW's Goliath|date=September 2015|accessdate=September 23, 2015}}</ref> In September 2015, the EPA said Volkswagen could be liable for up to $18 billion in penalties for using software on almost 500,000 VW and Audi diesel cars sold between 2009 and 2015 that circumvented [[emissions regulations]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.epa.gov/otaq/cert/documents/vw-nov-caa-09-18-15.pdf|title=VW Notice of Violation, Clean Air Act (September 18, 2015)|author=Phillip A. Brooks|publisher=US [[Environmental Protection Agency]]|date=September 18, 2015|accessdate=September 20, 2015|format=PDF}}</ref> unleashing [[Volkswagen emissions violations|a controversy]] that led to multiple regulatory probes worldwide.
In 2015 an [[ADAC]] study (ordered by ICCT) of 32 [[Euro6]] cars showed that few complied with on-road emission limits.<ref>[http://www.theicct.org/nox-control-technologies-euro-6-diesel-passenger-cars NOx control technologies for Euro 6 diesel passenger cars]</ref> In 2016 ICCT measured 19 new cars and found that real emissions were 40% higher than they were approved with, primarily due to the lax methods of [[New European Driving Cycle|NEDC]]-testing.<ref>http://www.theicct.org/sites/default/files/publications/ICCT_Coastdowns-EU_201605.pdf</ref>

Over the years, video game developer [[Namco]] has released various compilation-versions of their classic video games.
==''Namco Museum'' (series)== {{Main|Namco Museum}} ==''Namco Classic Collection Vol. 1 & Vol.2''== ''[[Namco Classic Collection Vol. 1]]'' and ''[[Namco Classic Collection Vol. 2|Vol. 2]]'' are two arcade machines, with both volumes including three Namco arcade games and updated variants of each game. ==''Microsoft Return/Revenge of Arcade''== {{Main|Microsoft Arcade}} Two compilations of [[Namco]] arcade games for [[Windows]] (specifically [[Windows 95]]) that were published by [[Microsoft]]. ==''Arcade Classics'' (CD-i)== {{Main|Arcade Classics (CD-i game)}} ''Arcade Classics'' is a compilation for the [[Phillips CD-i]] that was released in [[Europe]], but unlike the majority of Namco compilations, it was not released in [[North America]]. This compilation contains ports of ''[[Galaxian]]'', ''[[Ms. Pac-Man]]'' and ''[[Galaga]]''. ==''Xevious 3D/G+''== {{Main|Xevious 3D/G}} ''Xevious 3D/G+'' is a compilation of four [[Xevious]] games for [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] that was also released on the [[PlayStation Store]]. ==''Pac-Man Super ABC''== ''Pac-Man Super ABC'' is a compilation of Pac-Man games developed by Two Bit Score and released into arcades in 1999. It includes ''[[Pac-Man]]'', ''[[Ms. Pac-Man]]'', ''Pac-Attack'' (not to be confused with the [[Pac-Attack|puzzle game on consoles with the same name]]), ''Ms. Pac-Attack'', ''Pac-Man Plus'', ''Ms. Pac-Man After Dark'', ''Ultra Pac-Man'', and ''Piranha''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://twobits.com/16/|title=The SUPER ABC kit for Pacman or Ms Pacman|website=twobits.com}}</ref> ==Pac-Man anniversary arcade machines== On anniversary years of the release of either ''[[Pac-Man]]'' or ''[[Ms. Pac-Man]]'', a compilation of [[Namco]] arcade games would be released into the arcades. ===''20 Year Reunion: Ms. Pac-Man/Galaga - Class of 1981''=== ''20 Year Reunion: Ms. Pac-Man/ Galaga - Class of 1981'' was released in 2001, and was made to celebrate the 20th anniversary of ''Ms. Pac-Man'' and ''Galaga'', both of which are playable. Additionally, the original ''[[Pac-Man]]'' is playable by performing a special code using the joystick.<ref>https://www.arcade-museum.com/game_detail.php?game_id=8784</ref> ===''Pac-Man 25th Anniversary''=== ''Pac-Man 25th Anniversary'' was released in 2005 to celebrate the 25th anniversary of ''Pac-Man'', and also featured ''Ms. Pac-Man'' and ''Galaga''. Two versions of this machine were produced; one for arcades and another for homes, without the coin slot.<ref>https://www.arcade-museum.com/game_detail.php?game_id=13351</ref> ===''Pac-Man's Arcade Party''=== ''Pac-Man's Arcade Party'' was released in 2010 to celebrate the 30th anniversary of ''Pac-Man''. The cabinet includes ''[[Pac-Man]]'', ''[[Pac-Mania]]'', ''[[Galaxian]]'', ''[[Galaga]]'', ''[[Galaga '88]]'', ''[[Dig Dug]]'', ''[[Xevious]]'', ''[[Mappy]]'', ''[[Rally-X]]'', ''[[Bosconian]]'', ''[[Rolling Thunder (video game)|Rolling Thunder]]'' and ''[[Dragon Spirit]]''. Much like ''Pac-Man 25th Anniversary'', a home version was also produced, with ''[[Ms. Pac-Man]]'' as a bonus game.<ref>https://www.arcade-museum.com/game_detail.php?game_id=18630</ref>
==''Pac-Man Collection''== {{Main|Pac-Man Collection}} ''Pac-Man Collection'' is a compilation of four Pac-Man games for [[Game Boy Advance]] that was also released on the [[Wii U]] [[Virtual Console]], and included ''[[Pac-Man]]'', ''[[Pac-Attack]]'', ''[[Pac-Mania]]'' and ''[[Namco Classic Collection Vol. 2|Pac-Man Arrangement]]''.
==''Namco Vintage''== ''Namco Vintage'' was a compilation containing ''[[Galaga]]'', ''[[Dig Dug]]'', and ''[[Pole Position]]'' that was a downloadable game on the ''[[Xbox Live Arcade#Xbox|Xbox Live Arcade]]'' disc for [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] (not to be confused with [[Xbox Live Arcade]] for [[Xbox 360]]).<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=chqLMNEbXQo</ref>
==Namco Plug & Play games== {{Main|Namco (Plug & Play games)}} A series of ''[[Jakks Pacific|Plug It In & Play TV Games]]'' featuring Namco arcade games has had almost annual releases with either ''[[Pac-Man]]'' or ''[[Ms. Pac-Man]]'' being the main game included.
==''Namco All-Stars: Pac-Man and Dig Dug''== ''Namco All-Stars: Pac-Man and Dig Dug'' was a compilation of ports for Windows, and featured the original ''[[Pac-Man]]'' and ''[[Dig Dug]]'', and also featured versions of both games that added enhanced graphics and sound. The enhanced graphics for ''Pac-Man'' were from ''[[Pac-Man Championship Edition]]'' and the enhanced graphics for ''Dig Dug'' were from ''[[Dig Dug: Digging Strike]]''.
==''Namco Games Portal''== ''Namco Games Portal'' was an [[iOS (Apple)|iOS]] application released in 2010 that included several Bandai Namco-developed iOS games as well as games that could be purchased through the app. The games that were free to play were ''Letter Labyrinth'', ''[[Time Crisis 2nd Strike]]'', ''[[Pac-Man]] Lite'', ''[[Galaga Remix|Galaga Remix]] Lite'', ''[[Dig_Dug#Dig_Dug_Remix|Dig Dug Remix]] Lite'' and ''[[Ace Combat Xi: Skies of Incursion]]''.
==''Galaga 30th Collection''== {{Main|Galaga 30th Collection}} To celebrate [[Galaga]]'s 30th anniversary, ''Galaga 30th Collection'' is an iOS application that is downloadable for free and comes with ''[[Galaxian]]'', with its three arcade sequels available to buy as in-app purchases. ==''Pac-Man & Galaga Dimensions''== {{Main|Pac-Man & Galaga Dimensions}} ''Pac-Man & Galaga Dimensions'' is a video game compilation for [[Nintendo 3DS]] which includes two new games, ''[[Pac-Man & Galaga Dimensions#Pac-Man Tilt|Pac-Man Tilt]]'' and ''[[Pac-Man & Galaga Dimensions#Galaga 3D Impact|Galaga 3D Impact]]'', as well as ''[[Pac-Man Championship Edition]]'', ''[[Galaga Legions]]'', the original ''[[Pac-Man]]'' and the original ''[[Galaga]]''. ==''Namco Arcade''== {{Main|Namco Arcade}} ''Namco Arcade'' was an application for [[iOS (Apple)|iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] that was downloadable for free and allowed players to play each game for free once a day, with either the option to purchase the game in-app, or to utilize its "Play Coin" feature. The app featured ''[[Pac-Man]]'', ''[[Galaga]]'', ''[[The Tower of Druaga]]'', ''[[Rolling Thunder (video game)|Rolling Thunder]]'', ''[[Dragon Buster]]'', ''[[Motos]]'', ''[[Phozon]]'', ''[[Xevious]]'', ''[[Pac-Land]]'' and ''[[StarBlade]]''. The app was later delisted from the App Store on March 31, 2016.
==''Pac-Man Games''== {{Main|Pac-Man Games}} ''Pac-Man Games'' was an [[iOS (Apple)|iOS]] application by [[Namco Bandai Games]] that contained timed "S" (Score Attack) versions of six different Namco games along with social network features, with the games being ''[[Pac-Man|Pac-Man S]]'', ''[[Dig Dug|Dig Dug S]]'', ''[[Galaga|Galaga S]]'', ''[[Rally-X|Rally-X S]]'', ''[[Gator Panic|Gator Panic S]]'', and ''Pac-Chain S''.
==''Pac-Man Museum''== {{Main|Pac-Man Museum}} ''Pac-Man Museum'' is a downloadable compilation of ''Pac-Man'' games for [[Xbox Live Arcade]], [[PlayStation Network]] ([[PlayStation 3|PS3]]), and [[Windows]] [[Personal computer|PC]] (through [[Steam (software)|Steam]]).
==''Pac-Man Championship Edition 2 + Arcade Game Series''== ''Pac-Man Championship Edition 2 + Arcade Game Series'' is a retail disc containing three of the [[Arcade Game Series]] games (''[[Pac-Man]]'', ''[[Galaga]]'', and ''[[Dig Dug]]'') compiled with ''[[Pac-Man Championship Edition 2]]'', it was released for [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Xbox One]] on November 1, 2016 in North America.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.play-asia.com/pac-man-championship-edition-2-arcade-game-series/13/70am85 | title=Pac-Man Championship Edition 2 + Arcade Game Series | work=Play-Asia.com | accessdate=20 October 2016}}</ref>
==''Pac-Man Pocket Player''== ''Pac-Man Pocket Player'' is a [[Dedicated console|dedicated]] [[Handheld game console|handheld]] console developed by [[My Arcade]] that includes ''[[Pac-Man]]'', ''[[Pac-Mania]]'', and ''[[Pac-Attack]]'' (as ''Pac-Panic''). It was be released by Bandai Namco during July 2018.<ref>https://www.outrightgeekery.com/2018/06/12/namco-museum-mini-player/</ref> All of the games included are the [[Sega Genesis]] versions of the games including ''Pac-Man'' which is a homebrew port.
==''Pac-Man's Pixel Bash''== ''Pac-Man's Pixel Bash'' is an [[arcade cabinet]] that released with both a coin-op version and a version for homes that includes a compilation of 31 and 32 Namco arcade games respectively.<ref>https://www.bandainamco-am.com/game.php?gameid=71</ref><ref>https://www.bandainamco-am.com/game.php?gameid=74</ref> The games included are: * ''[[Baraduke]]'' (1985) * ''[[Bosconian]]'' (1981) * ''[[Dig Dug]]'' (1982) * ''[[Dig Dug II]]'' (1985) * ''[[Dragon Buster]]'' (1985) * ''[[Dragon Spirit]]'' (1987) * ''[[Galaga]]'' (1981) * ''[[Galaga '88]]'' (1987) * ''[[Galaxian]]'' (1979) * ''[[Gaplus]]'' (1984) * ''[[Grobda]]'' (1984) * ''[[Hopping Mappy]]'' (1986) * ''[[King & Balloon]]'' (1980) * ''[[Mappy]]'' (1983) * ''[[Metro-Cross]]'' (1985) * ''[[Motos]]'' (1985) * ''[[Ms. Pac-Man]]''{{dagger}} (1981) * ''[[New Rally-X]]'' (1981) * ''[[Pac & Pal]]'' (1983) * ''[[Pac-Man]]'' (1980) * ''[[Pac-Man Plus]]'' (1982) * ''[[Pac-Mania]]'' (1987) * ''[[Rally-X]]'' (1980) * ''[[Rolling Thunder (arcade game)|Rolling Thunder]]'' (1986) * ''[[Rompers (arcade game)|Rompers]]'' (1989) * ''[[Sky Kid]]'' (1985) * ''[[Sky Kid Deluxe]]'' (1986) * ''[[Splatterhouse]]'' (1988) * ''[[Super Pac-Man]]'' (1982) * ''[[Super Xevious]]'' (1984) * ''[[The Tower of Druaga]]'' (1984) * ''[[Xevious]]'' (1982) {{dagger}} denotes that the game is only included in the home version of the arcade cabinet.
==Japan-only compilations== ===''Disk NG''=== {{Main|Disk NG}} ''[[Disk NG]]'' is a series of two compilations for the [[MSX]] that contain MSX ports of Namco arcade games with also an exclusive game in each. ===''Namco Gallery''=== {{Infobox VG |italic title = no |title = Namco Gallery |image = |developer = [[TOSE]] |publisher = [[Namco]] |director = |designer = |composer = |engine = |released = |genre = Compilation |modes = |platforms = [[Game Boy]] }} ''Namco Gallery'' is a [[Japan]]-only series of game compilations for [[Game Boy]] containing [[Game Boy]] versions of [[video game console|console]] and [[arcade game|arcade]] games from [[Namco]]. This list covers optical '''lens designs''' grouped by tasks or overall type. The field of [[optical lens design]]ing has many variables including the function the lens or group of lenses have to perform, the limits of optical glass because of the [[index of refraction]] and [[Dispersion (optics)|dispersion]] properties, and design constraints including realistic lens element center and edge thicknesses, minimum and maximum air-spaces between lenses, maximum constraints on entrance and exit angles, and even cost. Some lenses listed are overall types with sub-designs (''as noted'').
==Simple lens designs== [[Simple lens]]es are lenses consisting of a single element. Lenses in this section may overlap with lens designs in other sections, for example the [[Wollaston landscape lens]] is a single element and also a camera lens design.
;Basic types * [[Lens (optics)#Types of simple lenses|Biconcave lens]] * [[Lens (optics)#Types of simple lenses|Biconvex lens]] * [[Lens (optics)#Types of simple lenses|Convex-concave lens]] * [[Lens (optics)#Types of simple lenses|Plano concave lens]] * [[Lens (optics)#Types of simple lenses|Plano convex lens]] * [[Lens (optics)#Types of simple lenses|Meniscus lens]] ;Designs * [[Wollaston landscape lens]]
==Achromatic lens designs== There are many compound designs of [[wiktionary:achromatic|achromatic]] lenses, designed to reduce color-related distortion ([[Chromatic aberration]]):
* [[Achromatic doublet]] (''type'') ** [[Achromatic lens#Littrow doublet|Littrow doublet]] ** [[Achromatic lens#Fraunhofer doublet (Fraunhofer objective)|Fraunhofer doublet]] ** [[Achromatic lens#Clark doublet|Clark doublet]] ** [[Achromatic lens#Oil-spaced doublet|Oil-spaced doublet]] ** [[Achromatic lens#Steinheil doublet|Steinheil doublet]] ** [[Apochromatic doublet]] * [[Dialyte lens]] * [[Superachromat]]
==Camera lens designs== [[Camera lens]]es use a wide variety of designs because of the need to balance and trade off different requirements: [[angle of view]] (i.e. [[focal length]] in relation to the film or sensor size), maximum [[aperture]], [[optical resolution | resolution]], [[distortion (optics) | distortion]], [[chromatic aberration | color correction]], [[back focal distance]], and cost.
* [[Celor lens]] * [[Joseph Petzval#Discoveries and inventions|Chevalier lens]] * [[Cooke Triplet]] * [[Double-Gauss lens]] * [[Frazier lens]] * [[Fresnel lens]] * [[Gauss lens]] * [[Retrofocus|Inverted telephoto (retrofocus) lens]] * [[Petzval lens]] * [[Plasmat lens]] * [[Telephoto lens]] * [[Tessar|Tessar lens]] * [[Wollaston landscape lens]]
==Eyepiece designs== An [[eyepiece]], a type of (usually a compound) lens that attaches to optical devices such as telescopes and microscopes, comes in many designs:
* [[Eyepiece#Convex lens|Convex]] * [[Eyepiece#Negative lens or "Galilean"|Galilean]] * [[Eyepiece#Huygens|Huygens]] * [[Eyepiece#Ramsden|Ramsden]] * [[Eyepiece#Kellner or "Achromat"|Kellner or "Achromat"]] * [[Eyepiece#Plössl or "Symmetrical"|Plössl or "Symmetrical"]] * [[Eyepiece#Orthoscopic or "Abbe"|Orthoscopic or "Abbe"]] * [[Eyepiece#Monocentric|Monocentric]] * [[Eyepiece#Erfle|Erfle]] * [[Eyepiece#König|König]] * [[Eyepiece#RKE|RKE]] * [[Eyepiece#Nagler|Nagler]]

'''Macro BIM''' (Building Information Model) is a [[building information model]], assembled of higher level [[building element]]s, used for macro level analysis including [[Visualization (computer graphics)|visualization]], [[spatial validation]], [[cost modeling]]/estimating, phasing/sequencing, [[energy performance]], and risk.
Macro models are intended to be built quickly, facilitating rapid [[analysis]] of multiple concepts or ideas prior to launching into a more detailed in depth study of a preferred concept using "Micro BIM" applications.
Macro BIM authoring applications often utilize [[parametric variable]]s and properties as well as [[inferencing]] capabilities to quickly build enough relevant data to facilitate analysis.
